embeds.title: Brew of Sharpness
embeds.description:
Common Potion / All / Downfall

Gain 25 Counter.

messages.content: Brew of sharpness is a common potion meant to deal damage. It is most often compared to fire potion and molotov, as they are the other single target high damage potions. Whereas fire potion is instantaneous, and molotov takes 3 turns, this is the middle ground, taking only 1 turn of damage to activate. There are great ways to mitigate this downside, mostly through having a highly defensive oriented deck, so characters like guardian and hexa's <ghost shield> help immensley with it. It's biggest weakness is that it doesn't prevent damage from happening immediately like a fire potion can, and it is also harder to control who it targets for aoe fights

embeds.title: Awakening Wheel
embeds.description:
Boss Relic / All / Bundle Of Bundles

When you play a Power card gain 2 **Strength** :p_strength:.
After playing 13 powers that cost 1 or more in one combat, gain Truest Power.
*Collected feathers apparently from the crow god Mazaleth, it being haphazardly slewn around the spire does not bode well.*

messages.content: good potion. Fire potion is just about always useful as it can deal the last bit of damage you need to finish of an elite or just any other enemy thats about to murder you. This potion's damage is delayed by 1 turn, but you get 5 more damage out of it. The 5 damage rarely makes a difference  though, as often fire potions are being used on enemys with less then the full 20 HP; but having another damage potion in the common potion pool does matter because it gives you far more reliable access to this kind of buff. Compared directly to fire potion this potion does have the downside of needing to be hit first; which also means that in an group fight you might get the wrong enemy with this. However often its only being used ageist a single target anyways (unless your just throwing it away because you have something like white beast statue). Vs multi hit enemies with 25 HP or less you wont take the full damage from the attack to use the counter anyways, which helps when every boss in downfall mode has multi hits. Planning ahead is also pretty useful for this potion, since if you know that you will be a bit short on being able to kill an enemy quickly. You can use this on a turn when you have block; its hard to learn this but it helps get more value of out your brews of sharpness. Lastly this potion also has some minor synergies with champ, such as with gladitor form which lets you keep some of this counter for later; its not big but its something to remember.
Overall its a bit worse then your standard fire potion, but not by very much so its still always appreciated when it shows up

I dislike this potion (and molotov, which is extremely similar), more specifically I dislike it being available to all characters. At least champ has gladiator form and preemptive strike, for everyone else this is very awkward because it's delayed, and because the damage will always hit the first enemy, so you can't control it's output very effectively.

Several people have already compared this to fire potion, and for good reason. You get a measly 5 damage more, but in exchange, you have to get hit to make the damage happen, which sort of defeats the point of a front-loaded potion. Fire potion (and attack potion, blessings of the forge, colorless potion, cunning potion, distilled chaos, energy potion, explosive potion, fear potion, flex potion, liquid memories, poison potion, and skill potion) have value specifically because they are frontloaded. You can use them to smooth out a bad turn and create more immediate output, often saving 15-20 health by killing an enemy that you can't block against effectively. If you have a brew of sharpness, you are just out of luck, it will deal 25 damage, but only after you get chunked significantly yourself. You have to use it very preemptively if you want to end fights faster, and it can't smooth out bad draws/turns effectively. It's also miserable in most AOE fights, since it can only damage the first attacking enemy, and you will need to get hit by them first. This can be disastrous in a fight like reptomancer, gremlin leader, gremlin gang, triple jaw wurm or tri slavers, and almost any of the previously mentioned potions would do a far better job smoothing out those fights.

At the very least, brew of sharpness is pretty decent against act 1 elites, letting you kill nob and lagavulin faster, and letting you quickly eliminate the front tri-sentry (though you are probably taking 20 damage on the second turn to do so). It's really bad after act 1 though, and is probably one of the worst potions you can get on average

I don't think any kind of buff would make me like this potion more, counter is just a really bad effect, and it's pretty much exactly the opposite of what I want from a potion (I see potions as one of the primary ways to mitigate the RNG of the spire and help fix bad hands/turns, saving you health, and sometimes the whole run)
It's actually not that bad against tri slavers since you typically take a good chunk against them anyways
Hits the wrong one though
Third one should die first (has vuln/entangle)
Tri slavers is all about killing the back slaver as fast as possible. Brew of sharpness can never do that
Both sharpness and moltov too slow or cant do it
At least sharpness is *okay* for hitting the front one
But a plain old fire pot is the best one here
I mean if you kill the front one doesn't it still help because then you won't be weakened?
I recently used sharpness to quickly handle front slaver because I could get the back one fast but I'd run out of fuel quickly after, but that was a unique case :watcherthink:
usually you're pretty safe after the back one dies
And yeah delayed damage is much worse than frontload but it's still damage and can allow you a little bit of leniency early on in a run
Especially against the other 2 act 1 elites nob and laga
Since both of those fights are essentially damage races
It is the worst damaging potion that is 100℅ a fact but it's not worthless
Is it on the same level as <snecko oil>?

embeds.description:
Rare Potion / All / Slay the Spire

When you would die, heal to 30% of your Max HP instead and discard this potion.

messages.content: Like usually you swap snecko oil out for a different pot
Instead of using it

so the draw is kinda wasted most of the time
and if the reroll whiffs, it might even just finish you off
I mean in an expensive deck then you have a better chance of high rolling a lower cost

embeds.description:
Rare Potion / All / Slay the Spire

Gain 1 Ritual.

messages.content: Didn't even realize that was rare
Wow

I totally agree with Kiku (as usual), this sharpness potion is both bad strategically, and not very fun game design, unless Downfall is deliberately trying to make potions in general worse and less reliable, as a design decision
(If that is the intention, it's a valid decision! There is lots of other player power in other areas.)
I don't personally think it's the case, but I wouldn't be opposed to it being the case
